captions.text:
E=mc^2 may be the most famous equation in
the world… but what you might not know is

that it isn't the whole story. It just describes
objects that have mass and that aren't moving.

The full equation is E, squared, equals m
c squared, squared, plus p times c, squared,

where p represents the momentum of the object
in question. This might all seem a bit confusing,

but in fact you can draw it as a right triangle
with sides E, m c squared, and p times c - and

just use the pythagorean theorem (a squared
plus b squared equals c squared) to give you
the equation.

Also, from here it's clear to see that for
an object that isn't moving and thus doesn't

have any momentum and thus p is zero, we get
back our good ole' friend E=mc2. On the other

hand, if the particle in question is massless
(like light), then mass is zero and we get

E equals p times c. This tells us that the
energy of a massless particle (like a photon

of light) is the same as its momentum (up
to a factor of the speed of light).

In fact, the closer the energy of something
is to p times c, the closer that something

is to behaving like light (I mean, look here,
this tiny little bit of mass is hardly mass
at all).

Anyway, as an example, an object's velocity
is equal to the speed of light times the ratio

of the object's momentum to energy - or pc
over E. If your momentum increases, p times

c gets closer and closer to equaling your
energy, so their ratio gets closer and closer

to being one, and your speed gets closer and
closer to light speed. But because of that

tiny little bit of mass, the momentum side
of the triangle will always be a little bit

smaller than the energy side. No matter how
hard you try to increase your momentum, it

never quite gets to the point where p times
c equals your energy, and thus your velocity

can never quite reach the speed of light,
all because the hypotenuse of a right triangle
is longer than its legs.

comments.text:
+motemok We know that E=hf, E=mc² and that p=mv (where v<<c). Now it's 
simple algebra. 
P=mv 
P=(E/c²)*c <----subbing in that m=E/c² from a rearrangement of E=mc²
P=(hf/c²)*c <-- subbing in that E=hf
Now we cancel the 1/c² with the c
P=hf/c but since f/c=λ we get: 
P=h/λ    This isn't the whole story though. 
For an electron it orbits the nucleus in what's known as a standing wave, 
where its circumference is 2πr. But we know it's a standing wave therefore 
there are n integer values of wavelength going around the atom. 
nλ=2πr but we know λ=h/p
nh/p=2πr 
pr=nh/2π
But what is pr? pr is angular momentum which comes in n units of h/2π
But h/2π=ћ
Finally we get pr=nћ, so both momentum and angular momentum come in 
discrete values of ћ, this means it's what's known as quantised.

comments.text:
+Rick Baartman A) Einstein may have regretted it, but a fact is that in the 
formulation of his famous formula he used it in that way. So, this video 
 incorrectly suggests that Einstein's formula is incomplete.

(Btw, the article  http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass_in_special_relativity 
 I mentioned already in my earlier response.)

B) When the Newtonian mechanics was extended to Einstein's relativity 
("extended" I mean in the sense that in Newton's theory velocity is already 
relative in mechanics, but Einstein extended it by including optics in the 
relativity, so that the velocity of light became invariant), in the 
beginning of the previous century, the notion of mass could be extended in 
two ways. The first possibility was to keep the mass as a relation between 
force and acceleration (inertial mass) and as the source of the gravitation 
force (gravitation mass). This leads to what is called the relativistic 
mass. The other possibility is to take the mass as an invariant property of 
an object, which leads to what is called rest-mass.
Both possibilities have there advantages and their disadvantages. Using the 
first possibility many formulas can be taken from classical mechanics 
unmodified, but with the understanding that mass is the relativistic mass. 
An example is the formula for the cyclotron frequency (
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyclotron). In addition, at least for me, it 
fits better with the classical meanings of mass (inertial mass and 
gravitational mass).

C) Einstein's formula is interpreted as the equivalence of mass and energy. 
Therefore, sometimes the terms rest-energy and relativistic energy are also 
used. The same objection against the term relativistic mass can also be 
used for the term relativistic energy. It is not invariant, etc.

D) I understand that if there are two notions (1 rest mass/energy and 2 
relativistic mass/energy) and both have two names with two prefixes, that 
the terminology could be improved if one term (mass) is used for one thing 
(rest mass) and energy for the other one (relativistic energy), so that the 
prefixes could be dropped. Alas, as long as only a minority of the 
physicists use this convention and the majority keeps using it in other 
ways, the misunderstanding will remain.

F) My conclusion is that it all comes down to convention and terminology. I 
don't think that we disagree concerning the meaning of Einstein's formula. 
Or do you really think that Einstein meant the rest-mass when he published 
his formula? It is clear that with m he meant the relativistic mass. If you 
don't want to call it a mass, but you want to give it a different name, 
that is not a problem for me, but I have not yet seen such a different name 
in this discussion.
comments.author: Fred. Zwarts

comments.text:
+Fred. Zwarts The concept of mass changing with energy was (a) regretted 
later by Einstein (1948), (b) Leads to complications such as having to 
invent different "longitudinal" and "transverse" masses, (c) is unhelpful 
in working out Hamiltonian dynamics, because it writes energy as a function 
of non-canonical variables.

A helpful article is http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass_in_special_relativity 
. 

As you mentioned your qualifications, I should also mention mine: I am a 
Fellow of the American Physical Society. I work directly in the field of 
the motion of particles in particle accelerators, annually teach a 
graduate-level course on the subject. You can find a relevant lecture here: 
http://lin12.triumf.ca/text/Talks/2014PHYS/lecture1.pdf

comments.author: Fred. Zwarts

comments.text:
a) I see that you do not go into my remarks that the increase in mass is a 
fact of life in day-to-day physics and that ignoring it result in much more 
complicated formulas.
b)  I will not go into your personal attacks. For me they are a sign that 
you find your own argument on the subject itself not strong enough. If you 
continue with these personal attacks, I will just stop the discussion.
c) I think that we have a problem with terminology. You understand mass 
only as invariant mass, or rest-mass, or zero-velocity mass, whereas you 
ignore the fact that the term mass is also often used for the full mass 
that increases with the velocity. Often the zero-velocity mass is indicated 
with m0 (0 as a subscript). Most people understand from the context which 
of the two possible meanings of the word mass, or the symbol m is intended. 
Often when the context is ambiguous, the word mass is prefixed with 
invariant, rest, total, full, relativistic, or other terms. 
From the context it is clear that Einstein in his formula meant the total 
mass, not the invariant mass, because, then it tells the full story, if 
not, the formula is incomplete and additional terms are needed which makes 
the formula unnecessary complicated and less elegant.
d) Also in other formulas, the symbol m is used for the total mass. See, 
e.g. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyclotron. (Here you also see what I 
meant with the difference between m and m subscript 0) Don't tell me that 
this is an out-dated article..
e) Gravitation acts on the mass. A photon has rest-mass zero. Still, it is 
subject to gravitational attraction. This shows that also the gravitational 
mass is used in the sense of total mass, not zero-velocity-mass.
f) You may be surprised that in such an exact field as physics, some terms 
have more than one use. But also physicists use common day language. It is 
very well possible that some physicists have tried to define a more exact 
terminology, of which your quotations could be an example, but they did not 
succeed.
g) My conclusion is that the whole difference of opinion comes down to 
terminology. By misunderstanding of the terminology and of the symbol m, 
this video makes the wrong claim that Einstein's formula is incomplete. If 
it were understood that the m in Einstein's formula stands for the total 
mass (you may name it differently, if you don't like the term mass here, 
but I don't know another name), than the whole video would not have been 
made.
comments.author: Fred. Zwarts

comments.text:
+Tom Do
Sure, so let us start with the classical momentum: *p* = m * d *x*/dt
where d *x*/dt is the derivative of the position of your particle with 
respect to the universal, newtonian time.
I'll use *bold* letters here to indicate vectors (postion is a 3-vector ... 
and so is momentum).
So d *x*/dt is the velocity of the particle *v*.

In special relativity there is no universal time, so one way to calculate a 
unique momentum for a particle is to use the rest-frame of the particle. So 
then: *p* = m * d *x*/dτ
with τ as the proper time (the time measured in the frame of the particle). 
Every observer will agree on this momentum, since everybody can agree on 
the rest frame of the particle ;) So this momentum is well defined.

But you want to know the particle momentum in *your* frame of reference. So 
we write:
*p* = m * d *x*/dt * dt/dτ
It looks like this is just a multiplication with dt/dt but in reality it is 
the chain-rule from calculus.
Again: d *x*/dt is the velocity of the particle *v* as measured by you. But 
we also need to evaluate dt/dτ.
You may remember that in special relativity t = γ * τ holds. So: dt/dτ = γ 
leading to:
*p* = γ * m * *v*
with γ = 1/sqrt(1-*v*²/c²)

If we compare that to *p* = m * *v*, we find that our classical formula is 
accurate for small *v* (the limes of 1/sqrt(1-*v*²/c²) for | *v* | -> 0 is 
1; | *v* | is the absolute value of *v*). As a rule of thumb we could say, 
for instance, that we are fine with using the classical formula, as long as 
the difference between the exact result and the classical result is below, 
let's say 0.5 %. And this is the case for  | *v* | = 0.1 c :
γ = 1/sqrt(1-0.1²*c²/c²) = 1/sqrt(1-0.1²) = 1.0050378...

Ok, that was a little bit of math but I hope it helped ;)

comments.text:
Well, it's a little more complicated than that. The full formula is:
E²=m²c^4 + p²c²

So if you have a massive body that has almost no momentum in a particular 
reference frame, then m²c^4 is much larger than p²c² for that body. And its 
energy can be well approximated by E = mc².
In the opposite case: if you have an object with a large momentum in 
comparison to its rest mass, like a light particle moving very fast or a 
photon (with 0 rest mass), then p²c² is much larger than m²c^4 and it's 
energy can be approximated by E = pc.

And while it is possible to always find a frame of reference in which a 
certain object does not move (except when that object has no mass - then it 
gets really complicated) and therefore has p = 0 and E is exactly mc², 
objects that do have a rest mass cannot loose it all the sudden. So if you 
have a massive object, no matter how big you make pc, mc² always will 
contribute a tiny little bit, causing E to always be a larger than pc. The 
exception, of course, are again particles without a rest mass (like light) 
for which E is always exactly pc.

Does that help a little?
